newsitem.title: BELGIUM: BELGIAN SHIPREPAIRER WINS $2 MLN TURKISH CONTRACT.
newsitem.headline: BELGIAN SHIPREPAIRER WINS $2 MLN TURKISH CONTRACT.

text.p: Belgium's Antwerp Shiprepair NV said on Wednesday it signed a $2 million contract, its largest ever, to replace 152 tonnes of steel in the hull of the Turkish bulk carrier ESRA 1.
"The ship ran aground in the port of Antwerp and suffered steel damage in the bottom," Antwerp Shiprepair's Commercial Director Jaap Hameete told Reuters by telephone.
Hameete said the 124,000 dwt capsized ESRA 1 is due to be delivered on January 31. The contract was won last week after an international subscription.
"After inspection it became clear that 152 tonnes of steel had to be changed in the fore part of the ship where it hit the ground," Hameete said.
The ESRA 1 is owned by Turkish Alba Ship Management, which is part of the Marti concern, he said. It also sails under Turkish flag.

Antwerp Shiprepair was launched in December 1994 on a 30-hectare site in the hear of the port of Antwerp following difficult takeover negotiations in the wake of the 1993 bankruptcy of Belgian Mercantile-Beliard.
The main partner in Antwerp Shiprepair is Kopcke Belgium (51 percent), part of Dutch ship's stores and spares company Kopcke Group, with 51 percent.
Other shareholders are Flemish regional government holding and investment company Gimvindus (25 percent) and Belgian Oil Services Marpobel (24 percent).
The yard's repair services include six dry docks, the largest capable of handling ships up to 180,000 dwt.
Hameete said the contract would not create any extra jobs at Antwerp Shiprepair, which was set up with a workforce of 155.
"Shiprepairing goes in huge waves. Four weeks ago we had no ship lying in the dockyards. Now it's full again," Hameete said.
"Whenever we face sudden staff shortages we go to the subcontractors market," he said.
He added that no other major contracts were immediately expected. "You never plan such things in advance."
He said Antwerp Shiprepair's set-up was tailor-made for the Belgian market and had enabled the firm to stay out of the red.
It made a modest profit in its first 18-month financial year from December 1994 to end of June 1996, he said.
